title: Matter Changes: Chemical and Physical

vocab.definition: A change that affects the form of a substance but not its identity
A change that creates a new substance with different properties
Characteristics that describe matter, like color, texture, or hardness
A change that can be undone to get back the original substance
A change that cannot be undone
The form matter takes such as solid, liquid, or gas
A physical change from one state of matter to another like melting or freezing
A combination of substances that keep their own properties
A mixture where one substance dissolves evenly in another
The substance that dissolves in a solution
The substance that does the dissolving in a solution
Matter is not created or destroyed in a closed system during a change
A starting substance in a chemical reaction
A new substance made by a chemical reaction
A solid that forms from a solution during a chemical reaction
A chemical change when a substance reacts with oxygen, like rusting
Thermal energy that can raise temperature or be released in reactions
Energy we can see that may be produced during some chemical changes
The ability to do work or cause change, such as heat or light
A chemical change (combustion) where a substance reacts with oxygen and releases energy
A process where a substance mixes evenly into a liquid to form a solution
A physical change that changes size or shape without changing identity
A property that can change during some reactions (evidence of chemical change)
How hot or cold something is; can change during reactions
A smell; a change in odor can be evidence of a chemical change
A chemical change (oxidation) that turns cut fruit brown

teachingNotes: Demonstrate physical changes like melting ice and chemical changes like burning paper. Have students observe and classify different types of changes. Emphasize the difference between changes in form versus changes in identity.

shortanswer.question: Give an example of a physical change and explain why it's physical.
expectedAny: change of state without new substance

shortanswer.question: Give an example of a chemical change and the evidence.
expectedAny: gas bubbles in vinegar and baking soda
cooking an egg - permanent change/new substance
temperature change without heating or cooling

shortanswer.question: Explain why cutting an apple is physical but browning is chemical.
expectedAny: cutting changes size; browning forms new substances
cutting doesn't change identity; browning is a reaction
physical vs chemical reactions from oxygen

shortanswer.question: Describe how heat can cause both physical and chemical changes.
expectedAny: heat can change state or cause reactions
heating can cause phase changes or chemical reactions

shortanswer.question: Why are some changes reversible while others are not?
expectedAny: no new substance vs new substance
physical changes are reversible; chemical usually not
identity stays same vs new substance formed
chemical changes make new substances so not easily reversed

shortanswer.question: Is dissolving always physical? Explain.
expectedAny: sugar in water is physical; acid reactions are chemical
if no new substance forms it is physical; if new substances form it is chemical
salt dissolving is physical; vinegar with baking soda is chemical

shortanswer.question: How can you tell if a change created a new substance?
expectedAny: evidence like gas, precipitate, color or temperature change
